To track cable systems, you must follow their markings: spray paint on the concrete, faded orange “Buried Fiber Optic Cable” posts alongside the road, and warning signs mounted on cable stations.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: San Luis Obispo cable route sign

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: When there is a telecommunications monopoly or duopoly, one or two companies carry all traffic in and out of a country. They can keep prices of capacity high and limits citizens’ access.
Telegraph hubs were often targets of airstrikes and invasion during wartime, and several were reduced to ruins in the aftermath of World War II. Many of these were never rebuilt.

In Rudyard Kipling’s poem, “The Deep-Sea Cables,” he describes the telegraph cables’ seafloor environment: “The wrecks dissolve above us; their dust drops down from afar; Down to the dark, to the utter dark, where the blind white sea-snakes are; There is no sound, no echo of sound, in the deserts of the deep; Or the great gray level plains of ooze where the shell-burred cables creep.” Here, the earth and the depths of the ocean seem far apart, even though human communication depended on movement through the deep sea.
Trawling – a form of fishing that involves dragging nets along the seafloor – sometimes includes cables in its catch, severing the network as it pulls them up.

In the telegraph era, cabled islands and cities were key sites of political and military power. They constituted a “cable threat” to any country that sought to control the land and seas of the Pacific.
At these coastal cable stations, you look out to see the vast ocean in front of you. Below it snakes the invisible submarine cable.

Underlying the technical infrastructure of undersea networks is a tight-knit cable community. Many cable workers have been in the industry for decades, and almost everyone knows everyone. These men and women often have a shared sense of purpose in creating the communications system that links their nations to the world.

In the coaxial era, the social landscape of cable stations changed dramatically. As former colonies gained independence, the network’s stations were reconfigured as gateways to new nations. Yet, currents extending through the cable station could be perceived as a continuing intrusion of foreign power. In the 1960s, anti-British rioting in Indonesia cut communications to Malaysia and forced staff members to move to Singapore.

Overland cables could become targets for attack, as happened during the Boxer Rebellion in China when telegraph lines were sabotaged. Australia’s transcontinental line was often disconnected by Aboriginals as well as the occasional lost cowboy who wandered across the landscape and cut the line in order to be rescued by cable repairmen.

The first global telegraph network followed the pathways of British Empire, linking together its major ports and remote outposts. In many cases, however, the effectiveness of undersea cables in actually securing colonies was an aspiration rather than a reality. Local leaders “distorted the facts to suit their own ambitions,” and in some places, the telegraph helped to charge a budding nationalism.

Formed in 1864, the Telegraph Construction and Maintenance Company soon became the world's largest cable manufacturer. By some reports it constructed close to 90% of the world's submarine cables over the next half-century. This map shows the vast spread of Telcon networks by 1903, from the company's hub in London, England to its peripheries in Asia, Africa, and Australia.

In the Cold War era, people who were not part of the network were rarely allowed inside the station. Cable station tours were few and far between. Yet on one rare occasion, to commemorate the Canadian Overseas Telecommunications Corporation’s “birthday” in 1975, local residents were given tours of the cable station building. They were shown the equipment room, power room, and storage depot, as well as a number of exhibits that demonstrated the company’s abilities in cable operation and repair.

When telegraph cables came ashore, they first connected to a small building on the beach, the "cable hut." This tiny structure protected the connection between the submarine cable and the attached land line.

Cables are considered “critical infrastructure” by many countries, a term that means they are critical to a nation’s economic, financial, and social stability. In a number of places, security measures have been increased to control cable operations. In the United States, a group of actors and agencies known as “Team Telecom” review applications and clear cable projects  – this group has made it increasingly difficult to land on American soil.

The geography of signal distribution is centralized in key locations. Less than fifty undersea cables extend outward from the continental United States, supporting almost all international data traffic. This number is high if one looks across the globe. Many countries have less than five external links. Stations at Lantau Island in Hong Kong, Keawa'ula in Hawai'i, and Chikura in Japan are central hubs for network traffic.

Wake Island has long been a temporary landing ground, a launching point, and a space of transition. In the 1930s, Pan Am flights stopped at Wake on their way across the Pacific, and this hotel was built to house them. Today, contractors and military men come and go, importing food, filtering seawater, conducting research, and scanning the Pacific. Like the signals and planes that once passed through it, few stay here for long.

To military strategists, telegraph cables were the most efficient and secure mode of communication with colonial territories, especially during wartime. Even when they did not actually increase control over linked lands, these systems represent a belief that undersea cables could secure economic and political investment.

For many, ocean waters might seem like a threat to undersea transmissions, a material that would intercept the electric signal and break the circuit. In reality, this threat is minimal. In some places, however, the rising sea and intensified storms pose an increasing risk to coastal cable stations.

Early cable stations were often self-sufficient and insular spaces. Guam’s cable station, like many of that time, was “self-contained”: it was intended to be fire, earthquake, and typhoon-proof, with its own water supply, sewage and refrigeration system (including an ice plant), and it was lit using acetylene gas manufactured on site.

One of Southeast Asia's largest offshore structures, Chevron's Platong II Gas Platform sits 200km off of Thailand's coast in shallow water not far from Songkhla. The project cost over $3 billion US dollars and is expected to generate 18,000 barrels a day of natural gas liquids. As cables string out across the Gulf of Thailand, they interconnect such platforms with high-speed telecommunications.
Terrestrial wires can remain without an insulating layer because air keeps signals from diffusing. Without insulation, signals on undersea cables would dissipate into a conductive ocean.

In the 1990s, telecommunications companies downsized. Alcatel reduced 48% of their workforce in undersea networks. AT&T cut 123,000 jobs between 1991 and 1995, 30% of its labor force. Much of the labor has been now been outsourced to network operations centers or delegated to computers.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: The first stage of laying a cable

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The crew of the SS Mernoo lashed floatation barrels onto this World War II surveillance cable before they lowered it into the ocean. The cable was used to monitor the seas near Papua New Guinea for Japanese submarines.

In early cable networks, an overland line was often the more dangerous option. While several sites on the Pacific Cable Board’s network were chosen to minimize the undersea segment, the company came to worry more about New Zealand’s “precarious overland route,” a notoriously unreliable link from Southport to Sydney, and a terrestrial line in Canada that was disrupted by winter storms, bush fires, and “unusual electrical disturbances.” Eventually more “secure” undersea cables replaced each of these terrestrial lines.

Deregulation, privatization, and speculation about the growth of the Internet drove a global boom in cable laying in the late 1990s. Between 1988 and 2003, the voice paths across the Pacific increased 1.6 billion percent. Stewart Ash, who worked in cable installation at the time, recollects: “Cable manufacturers were building factories all over the place. We had a cable factory in Southampton in the U.K.. We had one in Portland, Oregon. We had another one in Australia. People were pushing out 100,000 kilometers of cable a year.”  This boom vastly expanded the undersea cable system.
Like the bridges that span these waters, cables bridge continents, bringing together diverse cultures and forms of communication.

Between 1918 and 1922, three 446-foot wireless towers were constructed on the Sasebo coast. Two decades later, the coded message to attack Pearl Harbor, "Climb Mount Niitaka 1208," was likely relayed through the site. Although the towers fell into disrepair over the years, in 2011 a group sought to preserve the towers. One member of the preservation effort said, “Because the site in a way symbolizes the war, we use it as a place to teach the children about the war.” The Japanese government subsequently named the station a cultural asset.

The Champion West platform off the coast of Brunei is producing more oil than ever thanks to undersea cables. Shell, a company that has been active in the country since 1929, first implemented their "Smart Fields" technology here. Fiber-optic cables relay detailed information about seafloor conditions, including pressure and temperature, back to the base. With this influx of real-time data, oil workers make operational decisions more quickly, activate underground valves electronically, and increase their rate of production.

When the Vietnamese government permitted fishermen and soldiers to pull up cable laid before 1975 to sell as scrap, their plans went awry: fishermen pulled up two of the country’s three working fiber-optic lines (a significant decrease given that 80 percent of the country’s information traffic was carried by undersea cable). The government rescinded the right to salvage copper lines, began monitoring the route of the last cable, arrested the cable “thieves,” and planned an enlightenment campaign to inform fishermen about the dangers of cable theft.

The infrastructures of colonial empires could not have been built without the labor of slaves and indentured servants. Across the Pacific and Indian Oceans, people were removed from their homes and put to work on cities, railways, and cable systems. The expenses saved through this practice made transoceanic networks both possible and profitable.

Cable systems are vulnerable both to external hazards and threats from within: an immense amount of time, energy, and manual labor are required to sustain undersea networks, and without it, the infrastructure would soon fail.

Here, those who control the cable systems meet resistance. In 1900, the Boxer rebellion in China severed lines between Beijing and the coast, cutting the cable at Taku. Once colonial powers suppressed the uprising, the British laid undersea cables between Shanghai and Weihaiwei out at sea, where they could not be severed by opposition.

Following the 1964 Great Alaska earthquake, a tidal wave came ashore at Port Alberni, disrupting mills and distributing cars and homes across the town. The COMPAC cable was broken only seven miles from the city in a shallow part of the inlet and traffic had to be re-routed through San Francisco. It was not the earthquake itself, but the shock of the tsunami that caused the break.
White colonists often dismissed native beliefs as mere superstition. Yet such legends and folktales significantly shaped the development of cities and technologies.

Abandoned structures across the Pacific bear the traces of war. This telegraph station at Ishigaki Island was left to deteriorate after the American attack in 1945. Today it is a reminder of the trauma of past conflict. Bullet holes remain scattered across its walls and residents report that ghosts haunt the area.

Huawei Marine Networks faces a challenge. The company was formed in 2008, and represented a coming together of two historically different cable worlds: that of the British, who dominated the cable systems of the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, and the Chinese, who sought to dominate the technological landscape of the twenty-first century. The cable industry was hesitant to accept this new manufacturer and supplier of undersea systems.

Cable ships are enormous boats that can carry hundreds of miles of submarine cable below their decks. On today’s ships expansive control systems and seafloor measurement technologies ensure that the cable will land precisely along a projected route.
Gateways are strategic locations, centers of power where messages can be delayed, censored, or intercepted.

November 15, 1901: “THE CAUSE OF A CABLE INTERRUPTION. A fault removed a few months ago from the Eastern Extension Telegraph Company's Sidney-Nelson section at as great a depth as 330 fathoms was found to contain a tooth firmly fixed in the core or interior portion of the cable... An expert examination of the tooth proved it to belong undoubtedly to a shark, the exact variety of which could not be identified. Five species are known to exist in a depth of 300 fathoms, and one as deep as 500 fathoms.”

“Dual-purpose” cables serve both science and telecommunications. These cables include sensors on their subsea repeaters, and as a result, collect data on the movement of ocean currents; oxygen and greenhouse gas levels; seismic movements; and temperature. These systems could monitor for tsunamis and sea level rise, but they also raise concerns about sovereignty – they might be used for resource exploration or military surveillance.

In some places, obsolete cables are drawn up from the seafloor and re-laid to connect un-cabled islands. The PacRim West cable, a transpacific link, was retrieved from the ocean and used to construct a new connection to Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea: APNG-2.

The Tumon Bay cable station was built for a cutting edge transpacific telephone network in the 1960s. At its commemoration, Guam’s governor stated: “The station is a most welcome addition to our island, both functional and beautiful in its thin-shell, barrel vault roof design—the first of its kind on Guam… this roof contains exactly the same amount of concrete as a flat roof, yet is vastly more pleasing to the eye.” It was designed by a local architect, utilized local labor and materials, and was applauded for its connections to its environment.

At one point or another, these cities – now part of Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand, and Korea – were all under Japanese control. During their expansion across Asia and the Pacific during the early 20th century, the Japanese government laid cables to many of its new territories. The ocean provided a thick layer of insulation that protected lines of imperial communication.
These are hubs of commercial activity, where cables speed up both communications and economic exchange.

Cable stations are strategically valuable and have become targets during wartime. In 1914, the Germans attacked cable stations at both Fanning Island and Cocos Island with the aim of cutting major communication routes across the Pacific and Indian Oceans. During World War II, Japanese planes bombed the Sumay cable station in Guam. Severing undersea communications lines isn't a key tactic in war today, but cable stations still have to be located on friendly, accessible territory and secured from potential threats. For this reason, places like Fanning Island are no longer strategic hubs, while islands such Guam are.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: A new path across the Pacific

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The first fiber-optic private cable system across the Pacific was North Pacific Cable. Because the company wasn't allowed into existing telecommunications facilities, they were forced to pave an innovative path across the ocean, linking new landing stations at Miura in Japan and Pacific City in the United States.

On vast estates in the South Pacific and Indian Ocean, colonists from the West planted commercial crops, ranging from coffee and tobacco to rubber and palm oil. To make their profits, they exploited indigenous labor, in some places enslaving workers and in others setting up systems of indentured servitude. Undersea cables circulated information about plantation exports and commodity markets.
Since government agencies have the ability to scan communications that transit through cable hubs, many cable builders are now seeking routes that avoid known sites of surveillance.

In his spare time while working at cable stations across the Pacific, KC Cox invented this selenium magnifier, which boosted signals on their way across the network. In turn, the invention of these "regeneration" technologies put many cablemen out of a job.
Signal traffic rarely moves in a straight line between origin and destination. More often our signals move in a circuitous route, determined by economic and geopolitical factors.
The last two decades have seen the rapid spread of the “technology park.” These areas house a range of technology companies, often offering tax breaks and other incentives to lure development.

Jakarta has a long history of urban segregation. During the earliest years of Dutch rule, ethnic groups were forced to live in segregated villages outside the city walls. Modern Jakarta has been called “the city of thousand kampongs,” each village each with its own identity. Gated communities continue the legacy of colonial exclusion.
In popular beachfront areas, property values are high. This can be a challenge for the builders of undersea cables, adding additional cost to an already expensive network.

Cable ships and a maintenance depot supporting the entire South Pacific region were once located at Fiji. Since these ships had a largely Fijian crew, they boosted not only the region, but the local economy.

In Hong Kong, the technology park model has taken hold. At the former cable landing in Telegraph Bay is the massive Cyberport, “a creative digital community” with over 300 tenants working on the development of information and communications technology. On the mainland, several “Science Parks” and “Industrial Estates” foster the growth of Hong Kong’s tech industry, ranging from multimedia to pharmaceuticals. The cable station at Tseung Kwan O is located on one of these estates, alongside television stations and data centers.
Piracy can pose a problem for contemporary cable systems. Cable ships have to beware of pirates, especially in the Indian Ocean, and some cable crews arm themselves to prepare for hostile encounters.
Cables are often inspected and repaired by divers. In Kota Kinabalu, men descend to periodically check on the area's submarine power systems.

This seaside manhole, covered in dirt, marks one of several cable landing points on O‘ahu’s coastline. From here, connections link directly to California, Oregon, Fiji, and Guam, and reach onward to Australia, Japan, and much of eastern Asia. Though they exist at the periphery of our vision, these underground manholes allow access to the global undersea cable network.

On the horizon, huge white domes dot the landscape. These are "radomes," a protective covering that keeps sensitive tracking equipment safe from the weather and from would-be observers. At both of these locations, in the center of the Pacific and at its northern edge, radar has been critical to United States defense.
There is an entire marine maintenance industry that has to be funded by cable owners even in the absence of any breaks.

Cable companies must insulate their systems from social conflict. They develop strategies of insulation, ranging from fences to legal regimes, to ward off people that might interfere with signal traffic.

The Gulf of Thailand (GoT) Fiber Link Project is just one of many undersea systems that bridge offshore platforms, allowing the oil and gas industry to monitor, process, and analyze data about extraction. In this image, leaders of Thailand and CAT Telecom celebrate the project's launch in Bangkok, not far from Sri Racha. The Chevron Thailand president announced, “Technology and innovation are critical to increasing our our ability to conduct safe, reliable, and efficient operations...a rapid and reliable IT system is critical for operational performance.”

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: Gulf of Thailand Fiber Optic Project Commemoration

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The station at Cape St. James once stood in this open plaza. Since then, however, it has been razed and removed, all evidence of the telegraph station demolished.

Early in the Russo-Japanese war, the Japanese cut a Russian submarine telegraph cable, severing their naval base at Port Arthur from the Russian consulate in Chefoo. Given the ease with which wireless was intercepted and jammed, the Russians resorted to smuggling messages across the sea on small Chinese junks.

Even though international telecommunications companies compete, they often do so in a "friendly" way. They use each others' systems as backups and share the same resources for cable repair. Nobody in the industry wants the undersea network to fail.
Here you see stark contrasts in the landscape around you, between past and present, rich and poor, and those who are connected and those who remain off the network.

While recent cables encountered opposition from locals when they landed in O’ahu, on Hawai'i's big island there were celebrations upon arrival of a system from Tahiti, featuring traditional Hawaiian dance and song.

Pirates have long challenged the expansion of trade in Asia and the Pacific. The Wakô, literally translated as "Japanese pirates," raided the coastlines of East Asia for centuries. The Moro pirates of the southern Philippines wreaked havoc on Spanish shipping and settlements. Towns and cities, from Tschifu in China to Bauang in the Philippines, constructed walls, watchtowers, and communications networks to defend against pirate ships.
Long before cars, cables, and railways comprised terrestrial networks, roads such as the Tōkaidō in Japan and Farrington Highway in Hawai'i were well travelled by pedestrians.

Midway Island’s staff published The Gooney Clarion, “A Weekly Newspaper Published Every Now and Then.” An article in its Farewell edition records an “exciting day” on which a ship passed nearby the island, but “it is hardly necessary to add, did not stop.”
